Award.AwardTitle: Improving Earthquake Forecasting and Seismic Hazard Analysis Through Extreme-Scale Simulations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Earthquakes emerge from complex, multiscale interactions across time scales that range from milliseconds to millions of years within active faults systems that are incredibly difficult to observe. Large-scale physics-based earthquake simulations are essential scientific tools that can be used to better understand these hazardous natural phenomena. This project will develop physics-based codes for simulating earthquakes on Blue Waters and apply these simulation capabilities to improve existing hazard analysis methods. The very large scale computing and data management capabilities of the Blue Waters system will allow the project to develop and test earthquake models that capture physics in a more realistic manner, and to run simulations at finer resolutions and higher frequencies. The results will better quantify seismic hazards and their uncertainties.

This project will advance physics-based probabilistic seismic hazard analysis (PSHA) methods using numerical experimentation and large-scale simulations to increase the scale range in current representations of source physics, anelasticity, and geologic heterogeneity. Specifically, the research project will work towards seven computational objectives defined to improve our understanding of earthquake processes and advance physics-based PSHA: (1) Develop an empirically-calibrated physics-based earthquake forecast. (2) Develop a statistically sufficient, but reduced, rupture set representative of the new Unified California Earthquake Rupture Forecast. (3) Implement a new dynamic-rupture based kinematic source model to compute ground motions up to 8 cycles per second. (4) Evaluate the basin connectivity phenomenon observed in previous simulations to establish the importance of waveguide modeling at low seismic frequencies. (5) Investigate and characterize the influence of material and source models on the accuracy of ground motion simulations. (6) Validate and calibrate the rheological models used in simulations. (7) Test the physics-based hazard capabilities on a vulnerable embankment dam. The goal of this research is to improve the physical representations of earthquake processes and the deterministic codes for simulating earthquakes, which will improve PSHA practice in the United States and benefit earthquake system science worldwide.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Researchers from the Southern California Earthquake Center (SCEC), participating in the Improving Earthquake Forecasting and Seismic Hazard Analysis Through Extreme-Scale Simulations project, used the Blue Waters supercomputer to develop new physics-based earthquake ground motion simulation methods. The new methods were then applied to calculate improved estimates of ground motions and long-term seismic probabilistic seismic hazard analysis (PSHA) in California. PSHA is the scientific basis for many engineering and societal applications: performance-based design, seismic retrofitting, resilience engineering, insurance-rate setting, disaster preparation and warning, emergency response, and public education.

Intellectual Merit: This project advanced physics-based PSHA using the best available California Earth structure models and highly efficient scientific software to perform large-scale simulations targeted at: (1) validation of high-frequency simulations against seismic recordings of historical earthquakes; and (2) computation of CyberShake hazard models for urban areas in California to support the development of urban seismic hazard maps and their integration in national seismic design products. The research group evaluated how alternative models of the Earth structure affected ground motion and hazard estimates in simulations of well-recorded historic California earthquakes, and also compared the simulated ground motions to observed ground motions for relevant events. Through these efforts, the project was able to identify which California seismic velocity models most accurately reproduce ground motions from historic earthquakes, and then use these seismic velocity models in simulations of possible future earthquakes. Project researchers also studied how variations in earthquake rupture processes, such as the rupture direction and rupture speed of large magnitude earthquakes, impacted seismic hazard estimates for densely populated regions of California. The project then used these improved modeling methods and tools with Blue Waters to calculate seismic hazard models for densely populated regions in southern, central, and northern California.

Broader Impact: This project used physics-based computational models, observation-based 3D Earth structural models, and high-performance computing to improve seismic hazard forecasts for California, which in turn has the potential to improve PSHA practice in the United States and will benefit earthquake system science worldwide. The project translated basic seismological research into practical seismic hazard information useful to researchers, government agencies, and the public that can help to reduce the risk from earthquakes and improve community resilience. Using recently developed analysis techniques, we can show that physics-based seismic hazard simulations can help us quantify uncertainties in ground motions at the regional scale. This quantification is critical to inform risk-reduction strategies, especially for critical facilities such as large dams, nuclear power plants, lifelines, and energy transportation networks. The PSHA estimates produced by this project are under evaluation by civil engineering groups, who need accurate information about earthquake hazards for tall buildings in California, and by United States Geological Survey (U.S.G.S) researchers, who are producing updated seismic hazard estimates for the U.S. The project performed collaborative research activities with interdisciplinary teams that include geoscientists, computer scientists, software developers, and earthquake engineers. Through well-designed scientific and computational goals, and selected validation activities, participants from these disciplines have worked together to help prepare society for earthquakes by producing new, more accurate seismic hazard information.
